{{unreferenced|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox language |name=Lake Peipus |altname={{transl|ru|prichudskiy govor}} |states=[[Russia]], [[Estonia]] |region=[[Pskov Oblast]], [[Tartu County]] |speakers= |date= |ref= |familycolor = Indo-European |fam2 = [[Balto-Slavic languages|Balto-Slavic]] |fam3 = [[Slavic languages|Slavic]] |fam4 = [[East Slavic languages|East Slavic]] |fam5 = [[Russian dialects|Russian]] |iso3=none |linglist= |glotto= }} '''Lake Peipus dialect''' ({{lang-ru|Причудский говор}}) is a [[Russian dialects|Russian language variety]] spoken on both sides of the [[Lake Peipus]] in [[Pskov Oblast]], [[Russia]] and some counties of [[Estonia]]. It originated as a mix of Pskov and Gdov dialects of the [[Central Russian dialects|Central Russian cluster]]. As many other dialects from this area, it is often considered to be transitional between [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]]. Lake Peipus dialects also include some loanwords from the [[Estonian language|Estonian]] language. The dialect has been studied and described by Olga Rovnova of the [[University of Tartu]] who has conducted fieldwork in Russian [[Old Believers|Old Believers']] communities in Estonia. == Examples ==
{| class="wikitable" | ! !Lake Peipus !Russian !Belarusian !Estonian |- |''to row'' |griabcy |gresti |hrebcy |sõudma |- |''other'' |inšy |drugoj |inšy |teine |- |''permit'' |luba |razriešenije |dazvol |luba |- |''for'' |gli |dlia |dlia |jaoks |- |''he'' |jon |on |jon |ta |- |''Tuesday'' |avtorak |vtornik |aŭtorak |teisipäev |- |''tea'' |caj |čaj |čaj |tee |- |''sausage'' |vorstik |kolbasa |kaŭbasa |vorst |}
Lake Peipus dialect: '''Nie peckaj adiožynu, chto myt' i chystit' budie?''' Standard Russian: '''Nie pačkaj odieždu, kto myt' i chistit' budiet?''' English: '''Do not stain your clothes, who will wash and clean it?''' {{Russian dialects}} [[Category:Russian dialects]] [[Category:Languages of Estonia]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Lal Loi (Sindh)([[Lohri]]) |type = cultural |longtype = Seasonal, traditional |image = Happy Lohri.jpg |caption = Lal Loi Bonfire |official_name = |nickname = |begins = |ends = |date = 13 January |celebrations = Bonfire, song and dance |significance = Midwinter festival, celebration of Winter Solstice |relatedto = [[Lohri]] }}
'''Lal Loi''' is the [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] name for the festival of [[Lohri]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jhulelalmandir.org.in/evens.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714044155/http://jhulelalmandir.org.in/Evens.aspx |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }} Jhuelel Mandir</ref><ref>[http://sindhirasoi.com/2013/01/09/maakhiyah-waara-borindahoney-and-sesame-seeds-balls/] Sindhi Rasoi</ref> Prior to the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947, Lal Loi was celebrated in some parts of [[Sindh]]. On the day of Lal Loi children brought wood sticks from their grand parents and aunties and lit a fire burning the sticks in the night with people enjoying, dancing and playing around the fire.
[[Sindhis]] believe that the focus of Lal Loi should be on getting rid of old belongings and cleansing the mind in readiness of the festival of Tirmoor which is observed the day after Lal Loi by all Sindhis. Tirmoor is the [[Sindh]]i name for [[Makar Sankranti]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=fSPB64Fe5UQC&pg=PA93&lpg=PA93&dq=lal+loi+bhogi&source=bl&ots=5e0MCz_izI&sig=PnGvgXdFjiPVlBz0mbghSxrgpPQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yk_zUq-zN9OShgef64GIAQ&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=lal%20loi%20bhogi&f=false] J P Vaswani: Destination Happiness</ref> For Sindhis, [[Makar Sankranti]] means worshipping Lord Sun and flying kites.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/Lohri-gaiety-warms-all/articleshow/11468901.cms? Nidhin Singhi "Lohri gaiety warms all" Times of India 13 01 2012]</ref>
According to some, not all [[Indian Sindhis|Sindhis]] observe Lal Loi <ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/Lohri-gaiety-warms-all/articleshow/11468901.cms? Nidhin Singhi "Lohri gaiety warms all" Times of India 13 01 2012]</ref> and the festival may have been observed by people of [[Upper Sindh]] where historically there has been inward migration from [[Punjab]].<ref>[http://www.amilsindhis.com/origin-of-amils.html Amil Sindhis]</ref><ref>[http://sindhisbysurnames.wordpress.com/2011/06/19/aakash-raghanis-take-on-sindhi-punjabis/ All about Sindhis (Sindhi-Punjabis)]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=7Wd_BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA118&dq=sindhi+dress&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DHF1VfLOEoWxUaHBgPAO&ved=0CFwQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=sindhi%20dress&f=false Kumar, P. Pratap (2014) Contemporary Hinduism]</ref><ref>http://historyofpakistan.kamranweb.com/sindh/history-of-sindh.html</ref><ref>http://prosody.beckman.illinois.edu/jscole/objects/pubs-sindhi/1_Cole_Sindhi.pdf</ref> There are also linguistic similarities between the northern area of [[Sindh]] with the [[Punjab region]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=oMhmKS73XtIC&pg=PA3&dq=sindhis+baloch+origin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fSSOVYGRCMO5Ubb4gsgF&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=sindhis%20baloch%20origin&f=false Schimme, Annemarie (1974) Sindhi Literature, Volume 9, Parts 1-2]</ref> It is however difficult to establish where Lal Loi was celebrated in Sindh or if it is observed there now. However, the [[Indian Sindhis|Sindhis]] community in India celebrate Lal Loi annually where festivals are organised in places such as [[Indore]] where the festival is organised by the Sindu Sabha,<ref>[http://paper.hindustantimes.com/epaper/viewer.aspx] Hindustan Times: 12 01 2014</ref> [[Mumbai]] and [[Udaipur]].<ref>[http://www.udaipurtimes.com/sindhi-community-celebrates-laal-loi/] Udaipur Times, Gaurav Bhandari 13 01 2013</ref>
In places where [[Indian Sindhis|Sindhis]] and [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]]s live in the same city, joint Lal Loi/[[Lohri]] festivals are organised.<ref>[http://www.merinews.com/mobile/article/India/2014/01/08/punjabis-and-sindhis-in-jaipur-gear-up-for-lohri/15893757] Merinews: Dr Lalit Kishore 08 01 2014</ref>

{{Use Singapore English|date=November 2018}}[[File:MRT emergency plunger warning sign.jpg|thumb|A warning sign in the four official languages of Singapore that is found in all [[Mass Rapid Transit (Singapore)|Mass Rapid Transit]] (MRT) stations]] {{Life in Singapore}} According to the [[Constitution of Singapore|Constitution]] of [[Singapore]], the single '''national language of Singapore''' is [[Malay language|Malay]], which plays a symbolic role, as [[Malay people|Malays]] are constitutionally recognized as the [[Indigenous peoples#Southeast Asia|indigenous peoples]] of Singapore, and it is the government's duty to protect their language and heritage. “The national language shall be the Malay language and shall be in the Roman script […]” (Constitution of the Republic of Singapore, PART XIII) Also according to the constitution, the four '''commonly used languages of Singapore''' are [[English language|English]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Malay language|Malay]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]].
The three languages other than English were chosen to correspond with the major ethnic groups present in Singapore at the time: Mandarin had gained status since the introduction of Chinese-medium schools; Malay was deemed the "most obvious choice" for the Malay community; and Tamil for the largest Indian ethnic group in Singapore, in addition to being "the language with the longest history of education in Malaysia and Singapore".<ref name="Dixon (2009)" /> In 2009, more than 20 languages were identified as being spoken in Singapore, reflecting a rich [[linguistic diversity]] in the city.<ref>{{cite web|title=Language Policies Impact on Language Maintenance and Teaching Focus on Malaysia Singapore and The Philippines|author=David, Maya Esther|year=2008|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/17081287/Language-Policies-Impact-on-Language|format=PDF|publisher=University of Malaya Angel David Malaysia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Languages of Singapore|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=SG|work=Ethnologue: Languages of the World|author=Lewis, M. Paul (ed.)|year=2009}}</ref> Singapore's historical [[Early history of Singapore|roots as a trading settlement]] gave rise to an influx of foreign traders,<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> and their languages were slowly embedded in Singapore's modern day linguistic repertoire.
In the early years, the ''[[lingua franca]]'' of the island was [[Bazaar Malay]] (''Melayu Pasar''), a [[Creole language|creole]] of [[Malay language|Malay]] and Chinese, the language of trade in the [[Malay Archipelago]].<ref name="Bao & Aye (2010)">{{cite journal|last1=Bao|first1=Z.|last2=Aye|first2=K.K.|year=2010|title=Bazaar Malay topics|url=|journal=Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages|volume=25|issue=1|pages=155–171|doi=10.1075/jpcl.25.1.06bao}}</ref> While it continues to be used among many on the island, especially Singaporean Malays, Malay has now been displaced by [[Singaporean English|English]]. English became the ''[[lingua franca]]'' due to [[Crown Colony of Singapore|British rule of Singapore]],<ref name="Lee (2013)">{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=C.L.|year=2013|title=Saving Chinese-language education in Singapore|url=|journal=Current Issues in Language Planning|volume=13|issue=4|pages=285–304|doi=10.1080/14664208.2012.754327}}</ref> and was made the main language upon [[Independence of Singapore|Singaporean independence]]. Thus, English is the medium of instruction in schools, and is also the main language used in formal settings such as in government departments and the courts. As Singaporean [[President of Singapore|President]] [[Halimah Yacob]] said during her 2018 speech, “Through the [[Education in Singapore|education system]], we adopted a common working language in English.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.istana.gov.sg/news/speeches/2018/address-president-halimah-yacob-second-session-the-thirteenth-parliament|title=Address By President Halimah Yacob For Second Session Of The Thirteenth Parliament|year=2018}}</ref>
[[Singaporean Hokkien|Hokkien]] (Min Nan) briefly emerged as a ''lingua franca'' among the Chinese,<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> but by the late 20th century they had been eclipsed by [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]]. The Government promotes Mandarin among [[Chinese Singaporeans|Singaporean Chinese people]], since it views the language as a bridge between Singapore's diverse non-Mandarin speaking groups, and as a tool for forging a common [[Chinese identity|Chinese cultural identity]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hsktests.com/singapores-speak-manadarin-campaign/|title=English version of Speech in Mandarin by the Prime Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong|first=Chok Tong|last=Goh|work=Speak Mandarin Campaign}}</ref> China's economic rise in the 21st century has also encouraged a greater use of Mandarin. Other [[Varieties of Chinese|Chinese varieties]] such as Hokkien, [[Teochew dialect|Teochew]], [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]], [[Hainanese]] and [[Cantonese]] have been classified by the Government as "dialects", and language policies and language attitudes based on this classification and discouragement of usage in Non-Mandarin Chinese or "Chinese dialects" in official settings and television media have led to a decrease in the number of speakers of these varieties.<ref name="Abu Baker">{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090306-126699.html|work=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|title=One generation – that's all it takes 'for a language to die'|first=Jalelah|last=Abu Baker|date=2009-03-08|accessdate=2010-10-12}}</ref> In particular, Singapore has its own [[lect]] of Mandarin; [[Singaporean Mandarin]], itself with two varieties, ''[[Standard Singaporean Mandarin|Standard]]'' and ''[[Colloquial Singaporean Mandarin|Colloquial]]'' or ''spoken''. While Tamil is one of Singapore's official languages, other [[Languages of India|Indian languages]] are also frequently used.<ref name="Singapore Census 2010">"[http://www.singstat.gov.sg/publications/publications_and_papers/cop2010/census_2010_release1/cop2010sr1.pdf Census of Population 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113154937/http://www.singstat.gov.sg/publications/publications_and_papers/cop2010/census_2010_release1/cop2010sr1.pdf |date=13 November 2013 }}" (table 4), Singapore Department of Statistics. Retrieved 17 October 2014.</ref>
Almost all Singaporeans are [[bilingual]] since [[Language planning and policy in Singapore|Singapore's bilingual language education policy]] promotes a dual-language learning system. Learning a second language has been compulsory in [[primary school]]s since 1960 and [[secondary school]]s since 1966.<ref>See [[Language education in Singapore]].</ref> English is used as the main medium of instruction. On top of this, most children learn one of the three official languages (or, occasionally, another approved language) as a second language, according to their official registered ethnic group. Since 1 January 2011, if a person is of more than one ethnicity and their race is registered in the hyphenated format, the race chosen will be the one that precedes the hyphen in their registered race.<ref>{{cite web|title=Greater Flexibility with Implementation of Double-Barrelled Race Option from 1 January 2011|url=http://www.ica.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=12443|accessdate=3 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126071447/http://www.ica.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=12443|archive-date=26 November 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==English as the main language of Singapore== {{Main|Singapore English}} [[File:Sing signroundabout.jpg|thumb|300px|alt=A street directional sign in Singapore in English|All [[Road signs in Singapore|directional signs]] in Singapore are written in English.]]
Although ''de jure'' [[Malay language|Malay]] is the national language, [[Singapore English]] is regarded ''de facto'' as the main language in Singapore,<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.leeds.ac.uk/english/staff/afg/pragp3.doc|title=Epistemic modalities and the discourse particles of Singapore|first=A.F.|last=Gupta|editor=Fischer, K.|format=DOC|work=Approaches to Discourse Particles|publisher=Elsevier|location=Amsterdam|pages=244–263}}</ref> and is officially the main language of instruction in all school subjects except for Mother Tongue lessons in [[Education in Singapore|Singapore's education system]].<ref name="Dixon, L. Quentin 2005 p. 625-635">Dixon, L. Quentin. (2005). The Bilingual Education Policy in Singapore: Implications for Second Language Acquisition. In James Cohen, J., McAlister, K. T., Rolstad, K., and MacSwan, J (Eds.), ''ISB4: Proceedings of the 4th International Symposium on Bilingualism''. p. 625-635, Cascadilla Press, Somerville, MA.</ref> It is also the common language of the administration, and is promoted as an important language for [[international business]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moe.gov.sg/media/speeches/2000/sp31032000a.htm|title=31 March 2000|publisher=Moe.gov.sg|accessdate=2011-01-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306034004/http://www.moe.gov.sg/media/speeches/2000/sp31032000a.htm|archive-date=6 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Spelling]] in Singapore largely follows [[British English|British conventions]], owing to the country's status as a former Crown Colony.<ref>[http://blogs.nlb.gov.sg/ask/children/481 What are some commonly misspelled English words?|ASK!ASK!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303222846/https://blogs.nlb.gov.sg/ask/children/481 |date= 3 March 2012 }}</ref> English is the country's default ''[[lingua franca]]'' despite the fact that four languages have official status.<ref name=TanShermanp340-341>Tan, Sherman, p. 340-341. "The four recognised official languages are English, Mandarin, Tamil, and Malay, but in practice, English is Singapore's default lingua franca."</ref>
Under the British colonial government, English gained prestige as the language of administration, law and business in Singapore. As government administration increased, infrastructure and commerce developed, and access to education further catalysed the spread of English among Singaporeans.
When Singapore gained self-government in 1959 and independence in 1965, the local government decided to keep English as the main language to maximise economic benefits. Since English was rising as the [[global language]] for commerce, technology and science, promotion of its use in Singapore would expedite Singapore's [[Economic development|development]] and [[Economic integration|integration]] into the global economy.<ref name="digital.georgetown.edu">{{cite web|title=Bilingual education with English as an official language: Sociocultural implications |author=Pakir, Anne |year=1999 |url=http://repository.library.georgetown.edu/bitstream/handle/10822/551456/gurt-1999.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=[[Georgetown University Press]] |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LktvcHES?url=https://repository.library.georgetown.edu/bitstream/handle/10822/551456/gurt-1999.pdf |archivedate=10 December 2013 |df= }} ()</ref>
Furthermore, the switch to English as the only medium of instruction in schools aided in bridging the [[social distance]] between the various groups of ethnic language speakers in the country. Between the early 1960s to the late 1970s, the number of students registering for primarily English-medium schools leapt from 50% to 90%<ref>{{cite news|url=http://libguides.nl.sg/content.php?pid=57257&sid=551371 |work=National Library Board, Singapore |title=Bilingual Education |date=2009-11-12 |accessdate=2010-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002211453/http://libguides.nl.sg/content.php?pid=57257&sid=551371 |archivedate= 2 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> as more parents elected to send their children to English-medium schools. Attendance in Mandarin, Malay and Tamil-medium schools consequently dropped and schools began to close down. The Chinese-medium [[Nanyang University]] also made the switch to English as the medium of instruction despite meeting resistance, especially from the Chinese community.<ref>Deterding, David. (2007). Singapore English. [[Edinburgh University Press]].</ref>
There has been a steep increase in the use of the English language over the years.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Singapore English definition – Dictionary – MSN Encarta |url=http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/features/dictionary/DictionaryResults.aspx?refid=1861728232 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kwsaTgez?url=http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/features/dictionary/DictionaryResults.aspx?refid=1861728232 |archivedate= 1 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Singapore is currently the most proficient [[English-speaking country]] in Asia.<ref name="Healy Consultants">{{cite web|title=Singapore Company Registration and Formation|url=http://www.healyconsultants.com/company-incorporation/singapore-company-incorporation.html|publisher=Healy Consultants|accessdate=19 August 2013}}</ref> Then [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Education Minister]], [[Ng Eng Hen]], noted a rising number of Singaporeans using English as their [[home language]] in December 2009. Of children enrolled in primary school in 2009, 60% of the Chinese and Indian pupils and 35% of the Malay pupils spoke predominantly English at home.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_471530.html|work=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|title=Refine bilingual policy|first=Amelia|last=Tan|date=2009-12-29|accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref>
English is the native language of 32% of Singaporeans, but has the largest number of speakers if statistics were to account for speakers of [[English as a second or foreign language|English as a second language]].<ref name="ReferenceC">[https://www.webcitation.org/6Lku3t29G?url=http://web.archive.org/web/20070920004459/http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/papers/people/c2000adr-literacy.pdf Literacy and language], [[Singapore Census of Population]], 2000. [[Singapore Department of Statistics]] (December 2000). ()</ref>

==Singlish== {{main|Singlish}}
Singlish is an English-based [[creole language]] with its own consistent rules and [[phonology]] widely used in Singapore.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbu.bg/PUBLIC/IMAGES/File/departamenti/4ujdi%20ezitsi%20i%20literaturi/Doklad_Adrien_2.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127055450/http://nbu.bg/PUBLIC/IMAGES/File/departamenti/4ujdi%20ezitsi%20i%20literaturi/Doklad_Adrien_2.pdf |archivedate=27 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}.</ref> However, usage of this language is discouraged by the local government, which favours [[Standard English]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,501020729-322685,00.html|work=Time|title=A War of Words Over 'Singlish'|date=2002-07-22}}</ref> The [[Media Development Authority]] does not support using Singlish in television and radio advertising.<ref>{{cite web|title=Use of Language Article 21. a.|url=http://www.mda.gov.sg/RegulationsAndLicensing/ContentStandardsAndClassification/Documents/TV%20and%20Radio/PoliciesandContentGuidelines_TV_TVAdCode.pdf|accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref>
Despite this, Singlish is still widely spoken across the island and viewed by most Singaporeans as a trait that identifies them as uniquely Singaporean.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
==Chinese language== {{see also|Singaporean Mandarin|Standard Singaporean Mandarin|Singdarin|Singaporean Hokkien|Hokkien influence on Singaporean Mandarin}} [[File:Teochew Building, Mar 06.JPG|thumb|upright|The Teochew Building houses a prominent Teochew clan association in Singapore, the [[Ngee Ann Kongsi]]]]
According to the population census, Mandarin and other [[varieties of Chinese]] are the most common languages spoken at home. They are used by 51% of the population.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> The table below shows the change in distribution of Mandarin and other Chinese varieties, as well as English, as home languages of the resident Chinese population of Singapore in 1990, 2000 and 2010. It can be observed that the percentage of the population which speaks English and Mandarin has increased, while the percentage of those who speak other Chinese varieties has collapsed and is now limited mainly to the [[elderly]]. More recently, English is starting to displace Mandarin among the new generation of Singapore Chinese due to long term effects of the dominant usage of English in most official settings over Mandarin, the dominant usage of English as the medium of instruction in Singapore schools, colleges and universities, and the limited and lower standards of local mother education system over the years in Singapore.
