===Standard Mandarin=== [[Standard Chinese|Standard Mandarin]] is generally spoken as the ''lingua franca'' among the Chinese community in Singapore.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|last=Oi|first=Mariko|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11468401|title=BBC News – Singapore's booming appetite to study Mandarin|publisher=BBC|date=2010-10-05|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> Simply known as Chinese, it is the designated [[mother tongue]] or '[[Ethnolinguistics|ethnic language]]' of [[Chinese Singaporeans]], at the expense of the other Chinese varieties.
In 1979, the government heavily promoted Mandarin through its "''Speak Mandarin''" campaign. The [[Prime Minister of Singapore|Prime Minister]] [[Lee Kuan Yew]] stated that Mandarin was chosen to unify the Chinese community with a single language.<ref>Lee Kuan Yew, ''From Third World to First: The Singapore Story: 1965–2000'', HarperCollins, 2000. {{ISBN|0-06-019776-5}}.</ref> With the rising prominence of Mandarin in Singapore at that time,<ref name="Dixon (2009)">{{cite journal|last1=Dixon|first1=L.Q.|year=2009|title=Assumptions behind Singapore's language-in-education policy: Implications for language planning and second language acquisition|url=|journal=Lang Policy|volume=8|issue=|pages=117–137|doi=10.1007/s10993-009-9124-0}}</ref> politicians such as Lee theorized that it might overtake English,<ref>{{cite web|author=english@peopledaily.com.cn|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90776/90883/6759455.html|title=Mandarin will become Singaporean mother tongue – People's Daily Online|work=People's Daily|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> despite strong evidence to the contrary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.gov.sg/public/sgpc/en/media_releases/agencies/mica/speech/S-20090317-1/AttachmentPar/00/file/SMC%20Appendix%20-%20Dominant%20Home%20Language%20of%20Chinese%20Pri-one%20students.doc|title=Dominant Home Language of Chinese Primary One Students|publisher=Ministry of Education, Singapore|accessdate=2011-02-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226151824/http://www.news.gov.sg/public/sgpc/en/media_releases/agencies/mica/speech/S-20090317-1/AttachmentPar/00/file/SMC%20Appendix%20-%20Dominant%20Home%20Language%20of%20Chinese%20Pri-one%20students.doc|archivedate=26 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> From the 1990s, with the perceived increase in commerce and trade possibilities with [[Mainland China]], the Singaporean government promoted Mandarin as a language with high economic advantage and value.<ref name=TanShermanp341>Tan, Sherman, p. 341.</ref> Today, [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] is generally seen as a way to maintain a link to [[Chinese culture]].<ref name="BBC"/> However, due to fact that English is the main medium of language instruction in Singaporean schools, colleges and universities; as well as the limited and lower standards of local Mandarin Chinese education in Singapore and the dominant usage of English in most official settings, the standards of Mandarin Chinese among many young Singaporean Chinese has been dropping as more and more young Singaporean Chinese are speaking and using English more frequently than Mandarin Chinese.
===Other Chinese varieties=== Other Chinese varieties also have a presence in Singapore. Amongst them, [[Hokkien]] (Min Nan) used to be an unofficial language of business until the 1980s.<ref name="countrystudies">{{cite web|url=http://countrystudies.us/singapore/20.htm|title=Singapore – Language|publisher=Countrystudies.us|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> Hokkien is also used as a ''lingua franca'' among Chinese Singaporeans, and also among Malays and Indians to communicate with the Chinese majority.<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> As of 2012, according to demographic figures, the five main Chinese [[linguistic groups]] in Singapore are [[Hokkien|Hokkien-Taiwanese]] (Southern Min; Min Nan) (41.1%), Other Min Nan variants ([[Teochew dialect|Teochew]] (21.0%) and [[Hainanese]] (6.7%)) [[Yue Chinese|Cantonese]] (15.4%) and [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]] (7.9%) , while [[Fuzhou dialect]] (Hokchia, Hokchew), [[Pu-Xian Min]] (HengHua), and [[Shanghainese language|Shanghainese]] have smaller speaker bases. However, in this present day, the two most commonly Chinese varieties spoken today among the older generation, some of the middle aged and the few of the younger generation are [[Hokkien|Hokkien-Taiwanese]] (Southern Min ; Min Nan) being the dominant dialect and [[Cantonese]] being second. [[Teochew dialect|Teochew]], is being replaced by [[hokkien|Hokkien-Taiwanese]] (Southern Min ; Min Nan), while other Chinese varieties are increasingly less commonly heard nowadays.<ref name="howardscott.net"/><ref name=TanShermanp341/><ref name="singstat.gov.sg">{{cite web|title=Chapter 2 Education and Language |url=http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/popn/ghsr1/chap2.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68v13p3aH?url=http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/popn/ghsr1/chap2.pdf |archivedate= 5 July 2012 |year=2005 |format=PDF |work=General Household Survey 2005, Statistical Release 1: Socio-Demographic and Economic Characteristics |publisher=Singapore Department of Statistics |accessdate=2010-11-11 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Written Chinese=== {{Main|Singapore Chinese characters}} [[Traditional Chinese characters]] were used in Singapore until 1969, when the [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Ministry of Education]] promulgated the ''Table of Simplified Characters'' ({{zh|t=簡體字表|s=简体字表|p=jiăntǐzìbiǎo}}), which while similar to the [[Chinese Character Simplification Scheme]] of the [[People's Republic of China]] had 40 differences. In 1974 a new Table was published, and this second table was revised in 1976 to remove all differences between [[simplified Chinese characters]] in Singapore and China.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fagao Zhou|title=Papers in Chinese Linguistics and Epigraphy|date=1986|publisher=Chinese University Press|isbn=9789622013179|page=56|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NEzEo5Y8B3oC|accessdate=31 January 2017}}</ref> Although simplified characters are currently used in official documents, the government does not ban the use of traditional characters. Hence, traditional characters are still used in signs, advertisements and Chinese calligraphy, while books in both character sets are available in Singapore.
==Malay language== Bahasa Melayu the standardised form of the [[Malay language]], is the national language of Singapore and one of its official languages. It is written in a [[Latin script|Roman script]] known as [[Malay alphabet|Rumi]].<ref name="Constitution 153A">Constitution, Article 153A.</ref> It is the home language of 13% of the Singaporean population.<ref name="Tan (2014)">{{cite journal|last1=Tan|first1=P.K.W.|year=2014|title=Singapore's balancing act, from the perspective of the linguistic landscape|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/549872/pdf|journal=Journal of Social Issues in Southeast Asia|volume=29|issue=2|pages=438–466|doi=10.1355/sj29-2g}}</ref> Malay is also the ceremonial national language and used in the [[Majulah Singapura|national anthem of Singapore]],<ref>{{Singapore legislation|title=Singapore Arms and Flag and National Anthem Act|cap=296|ed=1985}}</ref> in citations for [[Singapore orders and decorations]] and military foot drill commands, [[mottos]] of several organizations, and is the variety taught in [[Language education in Singapore|Singapore's language education system]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} Historically Malay was written in the [[Jawi script]], based on Arabic. Under the British and Dutch Malay began to be written in Rumi. Efforts to create a standardised spelling for Malaya and Singapore emerged in 1904 by colonial officer Richard Wilkinson. In 1910 the Malay of the Riau Islands was chosen by the Dutch van Ophuijsen as the dialect for his book "Malay Grammar", intended for Dutch officials, standardising Rumi usage in Dutch territories.<ref name="Phyllis">{{cite book |author=Phyllis Ghim-Lian Chew |title=A Sociolinguistic History of Early Identities in Singapore: From Colonialism to Nationalism |year=2012 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=9781137012333 |pages=78–84 |edition=illustrated |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DBiezxw4IGQC |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> In 1933 grammarian Zainal Abidin bin Ahmad made further changes to Rumi as used in Malaya and Singapore.<ref name="Fishman">{{cite book |last=Fishman |first=Joshua A |title=The Earliest Stage of Language Planning: "The First Congress" Phenomeno |year=1993 |publisher=Walter de Gruyter |isbn=9783110848984 |pages=184–185 |edition=illustrated |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IAlVIY79lSIC |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> Many Chinese immigrants who spoke Malay were supporters of British rule, and purposely used Rumi when writing newspapers or translating Chinese literature. Printing presses used by colonial officials and Christian missionaries further spread Rumi, while Jawi was mostly written by hand. The transition to Rumi changed the Malay language due to the influence of English grammar.<ref name="Phyllis"/> In 1972 Malaysia and Indonesia reached an agreement to standardise Rumi Malay spelling.<ref name="Fishman"/> Singaporean Malays still learn some Jawi as children alongside Rumi,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cook|first1=Vivian|last2=Bassetti|first2=Benedetta|title=Second Language Writing Systems|date=2005|publisher=Multilingual Matters|isbn=9781853597930|page=359|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yDLVaYJkyHUC}}</ref> and Jawi is considered an ethnic script for use on Singaporean Identity Cards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ica.gov.sg/page.aspx?pageid=140 |title=Update Change of Name in IC |publisher=Immigration and Checkpoints Authority |accessdate=29 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202101218/https://www.ica.gov.sg/page.aspx?pageid=140 |archivedate=2 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Prior to independence Singapore was a centre for Malay literature and Malay culture, however after independence its cultural role diminished. Singapore is an observer to the Language Council for Brunei Darussalam-Indonesia-Malaysia which works to standardise Malay spelling, however it has not applied to be a member. It nonetheless applies standardisations agreed to in this forum, and following the Malaysian standard when there are disagreements.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Clyne |first1=Michael G |title=Pluricentric Languages: Differing Norms in Different Nations |year=1992 |publisher=Walter de Gruyter |isbn=9783110128550 |pages=410–411 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wawGFWNuHiwC |accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref>
Other varieties that are still spoken in Singapore include [[Bazaar Malay]] (''Melayu Pasar''), a Malay-lexified [[pidgin]], which was once an interethnic ''lingua franca'' when Singapore was under British rule.<ref name="Bao & Aye (2010)"/><ref>Gupta, Anthea Fraser, [http://www.hawaii.edu/satocenter/langnet/definitions/singlish.html Singapore Colloquial English (Singlish)], Language Varieties. Retrieved 2013-11-11.</ref> Another is [[Baba Malay]], a variety of [[Malay-based creole languages|Malay Creole]] influenced by [[Hokkien]] and Bazaar Malay and the mother tongue of the [[Peranakan]]s,<ref name="Bao & Aye (2010)" /> which is still spoken today by approximately 10,000 Peranakans in Singapore.<ref>Reinhard F Hahn, "[http://www.lowlands-l.net/anniversary/baba-info.php Bahasa Baba]". Retrieved 2010-11-18.</ref> Other [[Austronesian languages]], such as [[Javanese language|Javanese]], [[Buginese language|Buginese]], [[Minangkabau language|Minangkabau]], [[Batak languages|Batak]], [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]], [[Boyanese]] (which is a dialect of [[Madurese language|Madurese]]) and [[Banjar language|Banjarese]], are also spoken in Singapore, but their use has declined. [[Orang Seletar language|Orang Seletar]], the language of the Orang Seletar, the first people of Singapore and closely related to Malay is also spoken near the [[Johor Strait]], between Singapore and the state of [[Johor]], [[Malaysia]].
==Tamil language== {{Main|Indian languages in Singapore}}
Tamil is one of the official languages of Singapore and written Tamil uses the [[Tamil script]]. According to the population census of 2010, 9.2% of the Singaporean population were Indian origins,<ref>{{cite web|title=Census of Population 2010: Advance Census Release |year=2010 |url=http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/popn/c2010acr.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68v15isAU?url=http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/popn/c2010acr.pdf |archivedate= 5 July 2012 |format=PDF |publisher=Singapore Department of Statistics |accessdate=2010-11-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> with approximately 76.7% who spoke [[Tamil language|Tamil]] most frequently as their home language.<ref name="Singapore Census 2010" /> It is a drop from 2000, where Tamil-speaking homes comprised 82.9%.<ref name="Singapore Census 2010" /> On the other hand, the percentage of Indian Singaporeans speaking languages categorised under "others" have increased from 9.7% in 2005 to 13.8% in 2010.<ref name="Singapore Census 2010" /> Meanwhile, the percentage of the total population speaking Tamil at home has remained steady, or has even slightly risen over the years, to just above 4%, due to immigration from India and Sri Lanka.
Apart from Tamil, some of the other [[Languages of India|Indian languages]] spoken by minorities in Singapore include [[Kannada]], [[Malayalam]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]], [[Hindi]], and [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]].<ref name="Dixon (2009)" />
==Eurasian languages== {{see also|Kristang language}}
Kristang is a creole spoken by Portuguese Eurasians in Singapore and Malaysia. It developed when Portuguese colonizers incorporated borrowings from Malay, Chinese, Indian and Arab languages. When the British took over Singapore, Kristang declined as the Portuguese Eurasians learned English instead. Today, it is largely spoken by the elderly.<ref name="Voices">{{cite web|first=Charlotte|last=de Rozario|year=2006|title=Kristang: a language, a people|url=http://www.centralsingapore.org.sg/site/cscdc/voices/voices29/003_districttune1.pdf|format=PDF|work=Community Development Council|location=Singapore|accessdate=2010-11-18}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Other Malayo-Polynesian languages==
In the 1824 census of Singapore, 18% of the population were identified as ethnic [[Bugis]], speaking the [[Buginese language]], counted separately from the Malays. Over the centuries, the Bugis community dwindled and became assimilated into the Malay demographic. In 1990, only 0.4% of Singaporeans were identified as Bugis. Today the term Malay is used in Singapore as an umbrella term for all peoples of the [[Malay Archipelago]].
==Bilingualism and multilingualism== The majority of Singaporeans are bilingual in English and one of the other three official languages. For instance, most [[Chinese Singaporeans]] can speak English and Mandarin. Some, especially the older generations, can speak Malay and additional Chinese varieties such as Hokkien, Teochew, Cantonese, Hakka, and Hainanese.
===Bilingual education policy=== {{see also|Language education in Singapore}}
Singapore has a bilingual education policy, where all students in government schools are taught English as their first language. Students in Primary and Secondary schools also learn a second language called their "[[Mother tongue|Mother Tongue]]" by the Ministry of Education, where they are either taught [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]], [[Malay language|Malay]], or [[Tamil language|Tamil]].<ref>[http://cgs.illinois.edu/content/language-and-globalization Language and Globalization: Center for Global Studies at the University of Illinois] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510062844/http://cgs.illinois.edu/content/language-and-globalization |date=10 May 2013 }}</ref> English is the main language of instruction for most subjects,<ref name="Dixon (2009)" /> while Mother Tongue is used in Mother Tongue lessons and moral education classes. This is because Singapore's "bilingualism" policy of teaching and learning English and Mother Tongue in primary and secondary schools is viewed as a "cultural ballast" to safeguard [[Culture of Asia|Asian cultural identities and values]] against Western influence.<ref>{{cite web|title=Envisioning Chinese Identity and Managing Multiracialism in Singapore|author=Chan, Leong Koon|year=2009|url=http://www.iasdr2009.org/ap/Papers/Orally%20Presented%20Papers/Society%20in%20Design/Envisioning%20Chinese%20Identity%20and%20Managing%20Multiracialism%20in%20Singapore.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=University of New South Wales, Nanyang Technological University of Singapore}}</ref><ref name="Vaish (2008)">{{cite journal|last1=Vaish|first1=V|year=2008|title=Mother tongues, English, and religion in Singapore|url=|journal=World Englishes|volume=27|issue=3/4|pages=450–464|doi=10.1111/j.1467-971x.2008.00579.x}}</ref>
While "Mother Tongue" generally refers to the first language (L1) elsewhere, it is used to denote the "ethnic language" or the second language (L2) in Singapore. Prior to 1 January 2011, the Ministry of Education (MOE) in Singapore defined "Mother Tongue" not as the home language or the first language acquired by the student but by his/her father's ethnicity. For example, a child born to a Tamil-speaking Indian father and Hokkien-speaking Chinese mother would automatically be assigned to take Tamil as the Mother Tongue language.<ref name="Romaine, Suzanne 2004 pp. 385-406">Romaine, Suzanne. (2004). The bilingual and multilingual community. In Bhatia, Tej K. and Ritchie, William C. (eds). ''The Handbook of Bilingualism''. pp. 385–406. Oxford: Blackwell.</ref>
Since 1 January 2011, Mother Tongue is defined solely by a person's official registered race. If a person is of more than one ethnicity and their race is registered in the hyphenated format, the race chosen will be the one that precedes the hyphen in their registered race.<ref>{{cite web|title=Greater Flexibility with Implementation of Double-Barrelled Race Option from 1 January 2011|url=http://www.ica.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=12443|accessdate=3 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126071447/http://www.ica.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=12443|archive-date=26 November 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The Lee Kuan Yew Fund for Bilingualism was set up on 28 November 2011. The Fund aims to promote bilingualism amongst young children in Singapore, is set up to supplement existing English and Mother Tongue language programmes in teaching and language learning. It is managed by a Board chaired by the Singapore's [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Minister of Education]], Mr [[Heng Swee Keat]] and advised by an International Advisory Panel of Experts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bilingualism.sg/about-the-fund/about-the-fund |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141026042219/http://www.bilingualism.sg/about-the-fund/about-the-fund |archivedate=26 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Impacts of bilingual education policy=== The impact of the bilingual policy differs amongst students from the various ethnic groups. For the Chinese, when the policy was first implemented, many students found themselves struggling with two foreign languages: English and Mandarin.<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> Even though several different Chinese varieties were widely spoken at home, they were excluded from the classroom as it was felt that they would be an "impediment to learning Chinese".<ref name="Dixon, L. Quentin 2005 p. 625-635"/> Today, although Mandarin is widely spoken, proficiency in second languages has declined.<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> In response to these falling standards, several revisions have been made to the education system. These include the introduction of the Mother Tongue "B" syllabus and the now-defunct EM3 stream, in both of which Mother Tongue is taught at a level lower than the mainstream standard. In the case of Mandarin, Chinese students would study Chinese "B".
The Malay-speaking community also faced similar problems after the implementation of the policy. In Singapore, Malay, not its non-standard dialects, is valued as a mean for transmitting familial and religious values. For instance, ‘Madrasahs', or religious schools, mosques and religious classes all employ the Malay language.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kassim|first1=Aishah Md|year=2008|title=Malay Language As A Foreign Language And The Singapore's Education System. In|url=|journal=GEMA Online Journal of Language Studies|volume=8|issue=1|pages=47–56}}</ref> However, Malay in turn is facing competition from the increased popularity of English.<ref name="Dixon (2009)" />
In contrast to the language policy for Mandarin and Malay, Indian students are given a wider variety of Indian languages to choose from. For example, Indian students speaking [[Dravidian languages]] study Tamil as a Mother Tongue.<ref name="Dixon (2009)" /> However, schools with low numbers of Tamil students might not provide Tamil language classes. As a result, students from such schools will attend Tamil language classes at the Umar Pulavar Tamil Language Centre (UPTLC).<ref>{{cite web|title=Our function as UPTLC|url=http://www.uptlc.moe.edu.sg/cos/o.x?c=/wbn/pagetree&func=view&rid=1146697|publisher=Umar Pulavar Tamil Language Centre, Ministry of Education, Singapore|accessdate=2010-11-18}}</ref> On the other hand, Indian students who speak non-Dravidian languages can choose from [[Hindi language|Hindi]], [[Bengali language|Bengali]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] and [[Urdu language|Urdu]].<ref name="Dixon (2009)" /> However, as with Tamil, only certain schools offer these non-Dravidian languages. Thus, students will attend their respective language classes at designated language centres, held by the Board for the Teaching and Testing of South Asian Languages (BTTSAL).<ref>The Board (2014). ''Board for the Teaching & Testing of South Asian Languages(BTTSAL)''. Retrieved 18 October 2014, from {{cite web |url=http://www.bttsal.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=5 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018112038/http://www.bttsal.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=5 |archivedate=18 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2007, in a bid to enhance the linguistic experience of students, the Ministry of Education strongly encouraged schools to offer Conversational Malay and Chinese to those who do not take either of these languages as their Mother Tongue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nurturing language proficiency amongst singaporeans|author=Ministry of Education Media Centre|year=2007|url=http://www.moe.gov.sg/media/press/2007/pr20070820.htm|access-date=13 November 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028110113/http://www.moe.gov.sg/media/press/2007/pr20070820.htm|archive-date=28 October 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> By providing the schools with the resources needed to implement the programme, the Ministry of Education has succeeded in significantly increasing the number of participating schools. More importantly, the programme was also well received by students.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20080722-78012.html|work=Asiaone|location=Singapore|title=Conversational Chinese and Malay at more schools|first=Amelia|last=Tan|date=2008-07-22|accessdate=2010-11-13}}</ref>
===Challenges in the teaching of Mother Tongue=== The teaching of Mother Tongue (especially Mandarin) in schools has encountered challenges due to more Singaporeans speaking and using English at home. The declining standards and command of Mandarin amongst younger generations of [[Chinese Singaporeans]] continue to be of concern to the older generations of [[Chinese Singaporeans]], as they perceive it to be an erosion of [[Chinese culture]] and heritage.<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> This concern has led to the establishment the [[Singapore centre for Chinese language|Singapore Centre for Chinese Language]] (SCCL) by the government on November 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20080908-86448.html|work=Asiaone|location=Singapore|title=PM: Don't lose bilingual edge|first=Clarissa|last=Oon|date=2008-09-08|accessdate=2010-11-18}}</ref> The SCCL's stated purpose is to enhance the effectiveness of teaching Mandarin as a second language in a bilingual environment as well as to meet the learning needs of students from non-Mandarin speaking homes.<ref>{{cite web|title=SCCL|url=http://en.sccl.sg/|accessdate=2010-11-18}}</ref>
Despite government efforts to promote [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] through the [[Speak Mandarin Campaign]], the propagation of Mandarin and Chinese culture amongst [[Chinese Singaporeans]] continues to be a challenge because Mandarin faces stiff competition from the strong presence of English.<ref name="Lee (2013)" /> However, this situation is not only limited to Mandarin, but also Malay and Tamil, where rising statistics show that English is progressively taking over as home language of Singaporeans.<ref name="Dixon (2009)" /><ref name="Singapore Census 2010" />
===Foreign population in Singapore=== With the influx of foreigners, the population of non-English speaking foreigners in Singapore offers new challenges to the concept of language proficiency in the country. Foreigners in Singapore constitute 36% of the population and they dominate 50% of Singapore's service sectors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Population Trends 2009 |year=2010 |url=http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/popn/population2009.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63okaGChL?url=http://www.singstat.gov.sg/pubn/popn/population2009.pdf |archivedate=10 December 2011 |format=PDF |publisher=Department of Statistics, Ministry of Trade & Industry, Republic of Singapore |accessdate=2010-10-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Thus, it is not uncommon to encounter service staff who are not fluent in English, especially those who do not use English regularly.<ref>Jamie Ee, Wen Wei, "[http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090831-164714.html Sorry, no English]", AsiaOne, 1 September 2009.</ref> In response to this situation, the Straits Times reported that from July 2010, foreigners working in service sectors would have to pass an English test before they can obtain their work permits.<ref>{{cite web|title=English test for foreign service staff from July|date=2010-01-26|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20100125-194296.html|accessdate=2010-11-17}}</ref>
==Sociolinguistic issues== {{refimprove section|date=July 2014}}
===Politics=== Language plays an important role in Singapore's politics. Even until today, it is important for politicians in Singapore to be able to speak fluent [[English language|English]] along with their [[First language|Mother Tongue]] (including different [[varieties of Chinese]]) in order to reach out to the multilingual community in Singapore. This is evident in Prime Minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]]'s annual National Day Rally speech, which is communicated through the use of English, Malay and Mandarin.<ref>Government of Singapore. (2014). ''Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally 2014(Speech in Malay)''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://www.pmo.gov.sg/content/pmosite/mediacentre/speechesninterviews/primeminister/2014/August/prime-minister-lee-hsien-loong-s-national-day-rally-2014--speech1.html#.VEPZP_mSyoE {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826175126/http://www.pmo.gov.sg/content/pmosite/mediacentre/speechesninterviews/primeminister/2014/August/prime-minister-lee-hsien-loong-s-national-day-rally-2014--speech1.html#.VEPZP_mSyoE |date=26 August 2014 }}</ref>
Before the 1980s, it was common for politicians to broadcast their speech in [[Malay language|Malay]], [[English language|English]], [[Singaporean Hokkien]], [[Singaporean Mandarin]] and other Chinese varieties. For instance, during the 1960s, [[Lee Kuan Yew]] learned and used Hokkien frequently in his political or rally speeches, as it was vital for him to secure votes in elections from the Hokkien-speaking community. Similarly, [[Lim Chin Siong]], who was charismatic in the use of [[Hokkien]], was able to secure opposition votes. Facing competition and difficulty in securing votes from the Chinese-educated, [[Lee Kuan Yew]] also had to learn Mandarin, in order to win the votes from the Mandarin-speaking community.
Although the use of other Chinese varieties among the Singapore population has dwindled,<ref name="Singapore Census 2010" /> they continue to be used in election rallies as of the [[Singaporean general election, 2011|2011 parliamentary election]]. For instance, both [[Low Thia Khiang]]<ref>Phua, A. (9 February 2012). Teochew candidate key to their votes. ''The New Paper''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120217-328595.html</ref> and [[Chan Chun Sing]]<ref>Tan, L. (11 May 2012). Life after GE – Chan Chun Seng. ''The New Paper''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120509-344825.html</ref> were noted for their usage of different Chinese varieties during election rallies.
===Status of Singlish as an identity marker=== {{See also|Singlish}}
There has been a continuous debate between the general Singaporean population and the Government with regard to the status of [[Singlish]] in local domains. While the government fears that the prevalence of Singlish would affect Singapore's overall image as a world class financial and business hub,<ref>Tan, H.H. (29 July 2002). A war of words over 'Singlish'. ''Time Magazine''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://www.singapore-window.org/sw02/020729ti.htm</ref> most Singaporeans on the other hand have chosen to embrace Singlish as an identity marker and as a language of solidarity.<ref name="Harada (2009)">Harada, S. (2009). The role of Singapore Standard English and Singlish. ''情報研究'', (40), 69–81. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from {{cite web|url=http://www.bunkyo.ac.jp/faculty/lib/slib/kiyo/Inf/if40/if4006.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602055518/http://www.bunkyo.ac.jp/faculty/lib/slib/kiyo/Inf/if40/if4006.pdf |archivedate= 2 June 2013 |df= }}</ref> In an attempt to eradicate the usage of Singlish, the government then began the [[Speak Good English Movement]], encouraging people to use Standard Singaporean English in all contexts instead. Despite the success of the campaign, most Singaporeans surveyed still preferred the use of Singlish to communicate with fellow Singaporeans, and they also believed that they had the ability to [[code switch]] between Singlish and Standard Singaporean English, depending on the requirements of the particular situation.<ref name="Harada (2009)" />
Most recently, Singlish came into the limelight when [[Republic of Singapore Air Force]] pilots supposedly used the language to much effect to prevent their American counterparts from intercepting their communications during the 2014 [[Red Flag exercise]], resulting in a boost in support for the usefulness of Singlish among Singaporean netizens.<ref>Loo, G. (23 May 2014). Come in Kangkong Commander! Mr Brown gives his take on air force Singlish. ''The New Paper''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://www.tnp.sg/lifestyle/come-kangkong-commander-mr-brown-gives-his-take-air-force-singlish</ref>
===Preservation issues=== {{See also|Speak Mandarin Campaign}}
Chinese varieties (classified as dialects by the Singapore government), with the exception of Mandarin, have been in steep decline since the independence of Singapore in 1965. This is in part due to the [[Speak Mandarin Campaign]] that was launched in 1979. As part of the campaign, all programmes on TV and radio using non-standard varieties were stopped. Speeches in [[Singaporean Hokkien|Hokkien]] by the prime minister were discontinued to prevent giving conflicting signals to the people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/413581/1/.html|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|location=Singapore|title= Use of dialects interfere with learning of Mandarin & English|date=2009-03-06|accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref> By the late 1980s, Mandarin managed to some extent, to replace these varieties as the preferred language for communication in public places, such as restaurants and public transport.<ref>{{cite web|title=Inter-generational cultural transmission in Singapore: A brief discussion|author=Liang, Chong Ching|year=1999|url=http://archive.ifla.org/IV/ifla65/65cc-e.htm|publisher=Oral History Centre, National Archives of Singapore}}</ref>
The preservation of local varieties in Singapore has been of increasing concern in Singapore since the 2000s, especially among the younger generation of Chinese youths.<ref>Lai, L. (23 October 2013). Young people speak up for dialects. ''The Straits Times''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://www.straitstimes.com/the-big-story/case-you-missed-it/story/young-people-speak-dialects-20131023</ref> This sudden revival of other varieties can mainly be attributed to a feeling of disconnection between the younger and the elder generations, as well as a sense of loss of identity from their own linguistic roots for many others.<ref>Ng, J.Y. & Woo, S.B. (22 April 2012). Dialects find a voice. ''Today on Sunday''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://newshub.nus.edu.sg/news/1204/PDF/VOICE-tdy-22apr-p2-3.pdf</ref> While more work has to be put in to revive these varieties, the recent 2014 Singapore Teochew Festival<ref>http://www.teochewfestival.com/</ref> held in [[Ngee Ann City]] can be regarded as a positive sign that more people are becoming more actively involved in reconnecting with their linguistic roots.<ref>Mendoza, D. (25 September 2014). Singapore Teochew Festival: Celebrating tradition with modern approaches. ''Today Online''. Retrieved 19 October 2014, from http://www.todayonline.com/lifestyle/food/singapore-teochew-festival-celebrating-tradition-modern-approaches</ref>
===Controversy over learning of Chinese varieties=== In March 2009, a newspaper article was published in Singapore broadsheet daily ''[[The Straits Times]]'' on a Language and Diversity Symposium organised by the Division of Linguistics and Multilingual Studies at [[Nanyang Technological University]]. Dr Ng Bee Chin, Acting Head of the Division, was quoted in the article as saying, "Although Singaporeans are still multilingual, 40 years ago, we were even more multilingual. Young children are not speaking some of these languages at all any more. All it takes is one generation for a language to die."<ref name="Abu Baker"/>
This prompted a reply from Mr Chee Hong Tat, the Principal Private Secretary of Minister Mentor [[Lee Kuan Yew]]. In a letter to the editor in the Straits Times Forum, he underlined the importance of English and Mandarin over other Chinese varieties and how using these varieties "interferes with the learning of Mandarin and English"; a statement that Mr [[Lee Kuan Yew]] later corroborated in a speech at the 30th anniversary of the [[Speak Mandarin Campaign]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kchew.wordpress.com/2009/03/18/chinese-sporeans-should-focus-on-learning-mandarin-well-says-mm-lee/|type=reprint|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|title=Chinese S'poreans should focus on learning Mandarin well, says MM Lee|first=Pearl|last=Forss|date=2009-03-17|accessdate=2014-02-01}}</ref> Referring to the progress of Singapore's bilingual education policy over the decades, Mr Chee Hong Tat also commented that "it would be stupid for any Singapore agency or NTU to advocate the learning of dialects, which must be at the expense of English and Mandarin."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090311-127699.html|work=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|title=Foolish to advocate the learning of dialects|date=2009-03-09|accessdate=2010-10-12}}</ref>
===Renewed interest in learning other Chinese varieties=== Since 2000, there has been an renewed interest in other Chinese varieties among Singaporean Chinese.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Ethnographic Survey of Language Use, Attitudes and Beliefs of Singaporean Daoist Youths |author=Phyllis Ghim-Lian Chew |year=2009 |url=http://www.ari.nus.edu.sg/docs/wps/wps09_118.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Asian Research Institute, [[Nanyang Technological University]] |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ll3lh6mA?url=http://www.ari.nus.edu.sg/docs/wps/wps09_118.pdf |archivedate=10 December 2013 |df= }} ()</ref> In 2002, clan associations such as Hainanese Association of Singapore (Kheng Chiu Hwee Kuan) and [[Teochew Poit Ip Huay Kuan]] started classes to teach other Chinese varieties.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090408-134113.html|work=The Straits Times|title=Dialects draw more new learners|date=2009-04-09|accessdate=2010-11-17}}</ref> This was in response to an increased desire among Singaporeans to reconnect with their Chinese heritage and culture through learning other Chinese varieties. In 2007, a group of 140 students from Paya Lebar Methodist Girls' Primary School learnt Hokkien-Taiwanese and Cantonese as an effort to communicate better with the elderly. The elderly themselves taught the students the varieties. The programme was organised in the hope of bridging the generational gap that was formed due to the suppression of these dialects in Singapore.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/274568/1/.html|work=ChannelNewAsia|location=Singapore|title=Students learn dialect to communicate with elderly|first=Jessica|last=Yeo|date=2007-05-06|accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref>
Likewise, third-year students from Dunman High can now take a module called "Pop Song Culture". This module lets them learn about pop culture in different dialect groups through pop songs from the 70s and 80s performed in different varieties. Besides this, students can also take an elective on different flavours and food cultures from various dialect groups.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/today20080421-2.2.2.2.aspx|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|location=Singapore|title=Dialects spark new bonding|first=Lin|last=Yanqin|date=2008-04-21|accessdate=2014-02-01}}</ref>
Although the Singapore government appears to have relaxed its stance towards Chinese varieties in recent years, the fact is that they still did not actively support the widespread use of other Chinese varieties especially in the Singapore mainstream Television media. Recently, the Singapore Government allowed some local produced mini "chinese dialect" shows to be broadcast in Hokkien-Taiwanese and Cantonese dedicated to the Singapore Chinese elderly who speak Hokkien-Taiwanese or Cantonese but did not understand English or Mandarin Chinese. The aim of the local produced mini "chinese dialect" shows is to transmit important messages about social services and medical services and care to the Singapore Chinese Elderly. However, there are limited amount of "Chinese Dialect" shows that could be broadcast on Singapore's Mainstream Television due to the Singapore's Government strigent language policy.
==Linguistic landscape of Singapore== The multi-ethnic background of Singapore's society can be seen in its [[linguistic landscape]]. While English dominates as the working language of Singapore, the city does not possess a monolingual linguistic landscape. These can be seen from the variety of signs strewn around the city. Signs are colour-coded and categorised by their respective functions: for example, signs which are pointing to attractions are brown with white words, while road signs and street names are green with white words. Some of the most evident signs of multilingualism in Singapore's linguistic landscape include danger/warning signs at construction sites, as well as road signs for tourist attractions. By observing the variation in languages used in the different contexts, we are able to obtain information on the ethnolinguistic vitality of the country.
===Tourist attractions=== [[File:Signs to the Burmese Buddhist Temple and Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall, Singapore.jpg|thumb|Road signs to the [[Buddhist Burmese Temple]] and the [[Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall]]. The non-English languages used on the signs appear to depend upon the expected visitors to each place (only English and Chinese for the Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall sign, but those two plus [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[Burmese language|Burmese]] for the Burmese Buddhist Temple sign).]]
The majority of Singapore's tourist attractions provide information through [[English language|English]] in the [[Latin script|Roman script]]. In many cases, the entrances of the attraction is written in English (usually with no other accompanying languages) while the distinctive brown road signs seen along streets and expressways which direct tourists come in up to four or five languages, with English as the largest and most prominent language on the sign.
Some examples of the different ways in which [[List of tourist attractions in Singapore|popular tourist attractions in Singapore]] display ethnolinguistic diversity can be seen at tourist attractions such as [[Telok Ayer Market|Lau Pa Sat]], where the words "Lau Pa Sat" on the directory boards consist of the [[Mandarin Chinese]] word ''lau'' for "old" (老;''lăo'') and from the [[Hokkien]] words ''pa sat'' for "market" (巴刹;''bā sha''), written in roman script. The entrance sign of the attraction also includes a [[translation|non-literal translation]] in English below its traditional name (Festival Market). It is also called the Telok Ayer Market, a name which makes reference to the location of the attraction and does not have anything to do with its cultural name.
The conversion and expression in Roman script of Mandarin and Hokkien into [[Pinyin|''pīnyīn'']] helps non-Mandarin and non-Hokkien speakers with the pronunciation of the name of a place whilst remaining in tandem with the use of English and Roman script in Singapore. The repackaging of the original names of Lau Pa Sat in Roman script, and inclusion of the appearance of an English translation as a secondary title can be seen as a way of heightening the sense of authenticity and heritage of the attraction as it is marketed as a culturally-rich area in Singapore, similar to [[Chinatown, Singapore|Chinatown]] and [[Little India, Singapore|Little India]]; both of which were formerly cultural enclaves of the distinctive races. Similarly in places that bear cultural significance, the signs are printed in the language associated with the culture, such as The [[Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall]] which has an entirely Chinese sign without any translations.
Some notable exceptions include the brown directional road signs for the [[Merlion Park]] which are written not only in the four national languages, but also in Japanese. Although many variations exist, this arrangement is widely applied to most places of interest as well as places of worship, such as the [[Burmese Buddhist Temple]] which has signs in Burmese and some mosques in Singapore which also have their names printed in the Jawi script even though the Malay language was standardized with the Roman alphabet in Singapore.
===Government offices and public buildings=== [[File:Singaporeparliament2012.JPG|thumb|English signage at the Singapore Parliament]] Despite the fact that Malay is the national language of Singapore, government buildings are often indicated by signs in English and not Malay. Comparing the relative occurrences of English and Malay in building signs, the use of the working language is far more common in Singapore's linguistic landscape than that of the national language, which is limited to ceremonial purposes. This can also be seen on the entrance sign to most Ministries and government buildings, which are expressed only in English, the working language.
Most of the foreign embassies in Singapore are able to use their own national or working languages as a representation of their respective embassies in Singapore, as long as their language can be expressed in the script of any of Singapore's official languages. For example, embassies representing non-English speaking countries such as the French Embassy are allowed to use their own languages because the language can be expressed in Roman script, thus explaining why the French embassy uses its French name. However, for the case of the Royal Thai Embassy, English was chosen to represent it in Singapore because the Thai script is not recognized as a script in any of Singapore's official languages, even though English is less widely used in Thailand than standard Thai.
===Public hospitals=== Out of the eight general hospitals overseen by [[Ministry of Health (Singapore)|Singapore's Ministry of Health]], only [[Singapore General Hospital]] has signages in the four official languages. Along Hospital Drive (where Singapore General Hospital is located) and various national medical centres, road directories are entirely in English. Within the hospital itself, signs for individual blocks, wards, Accident and Emergency department, Specialist Outpatient Clinics, National Heart Centre and National Cancer Centre have signs written in the four official languages. The English titles are still expressed with the largest font first, followed by Malay, Chinese and Tamil in smaller but equally-sized fonts, which is in accordance with order given by Singapore's constitution. Surprisingly, the Health Promotion Board, National Eye and Dental Centres, which are also in the same region, have English signs only. All of the other seven public hospitals have their "Accident and Emergency" sign in English only, with some highlighted in a red background.
===Notices and campaigns=== [[File:Sign indicating a ban on public consumption of alcohol, Little India, Singapore - 20141019.jpg|thumb|An advisory poster found in [[Little India, Singapore|Little India]] with information regarding the sale of alcohol]]
Messages and campaigns that have a very specific target audience and purpose are usually printed in the language of intended readers. For example, the "No Alcohol" signs put up along Little India after the [[2013 Little India riot|Little India Riots]] are notably printed in only Tamil and English as a reflection of the racial demographics in the region.
During the 2003 [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome|SARS]] epidemic, the government relied heavily on the media to emphasise the importance of personal hygiene, and also to educate the general public on the symptoms of SARS, in which a [[Singlish]] rap video featuring [[Gurmit Singh]] as [[Phua Chu Kang Pte Ltd|Phua Chu Kang]] was used as the main medium. Similarly in 2014, the Pioneer Generation Package<ref>https://www.pioneers.sg/en-sg/FAQs/Pages/FAQs.aspxh</ref> (for senior citizens above 65 years of age in 2014 who obtained Singapore citizenship on or before 31 December 1986) made use of Chinese varieties commonly spoken in Singapore such as Hokkien, Cantonese and Teochew, and also Singlish in order to make the policies more relatable,<ref>http://app.mof.gov.sg/newsroom_details.aspx?type=forum&cmpar_year=2014&news_sid=20140530447224514396</ref> and at the same time raise awareness about the benefits that this new scheme provides for them. These allowances of different language varieties is an exception to the four official languages. This exception is seen for campaigns that are deemed as highly important, and include the elderly, or those who are not as proficient in the English language as the target audience.
===Limitations in current research methodologies=== [[File:Signs to visitor attractions in the Civic District, Singapore.jpg|thumb|Different non-English languages appearing on directional road signs in Singapore]]
While the above examples show how the different languages are used on signs within Singapore, there is scant data on the motivations behind these variations seen, as exemplified by the advisory for "No Alcohol" sales in Little India, which showcased a rare variation from the usage of the four main languages that are commonly seen on most advisory signs. Similarly, the Ministry of Health, in a response to a feedback requesting all hospitals to have four languages on its entrances, has claimed that usage of pictorial signages was better in conveying messages, as opposed to using all four languages.<ref>https://www.moh.gov.sg/content/moh_web/home/pressRoom/Parliamentary_QA/2007/Hospital_Signages.html</ref> Due to problems in the research methodology<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tufi|first1=Stefania|last2=Blackwood|first2=Robert|year=2010|title=Trademarks in the linguistic landscape: methodological and theoretical challenges in qualifying brand names in the public space|url=|journal=International Journal of Multilingualism|volume=7|issue=3|pages=197–210|doi=10.1080/14790710903568417}}</ref> and lack of governmental statutes that explain these variations, the study on the linguistics landscape in Singapore remain as a controversial field. These problems include non-linearity, where the large numbers of variations seen in Singapore prevents the application of any trends to understand the landscape; and also the lack of any standard legislation that determines any fixed rules on usage of languages on signs.
===Controversies=== [[File:Signs to Lau Pa Sat and Merlion Park, Singapore - 20141019.jpg|thumb|left|Lau Pa Sat sign with incorrect translations]]
In a 2012 pilot program, SMRT trains began announcements of station names in both English and Mandarin Chinese so as to help Mandarin Chinese-speaking senior citizens cope better with the sudden increase in new stations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://features.insing.com/feature/tabloid-online-protest-mrt-station-chinese-name-id-53673f00/id-53673f00 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006135639/http://features.insing.com/feature/tabloid-online-protest-mrt-station-chinese-name-id-53673f00/id-53673f00/ |archivedate=6 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> However, this received mixed reactions from the public. Some people pointed out that there were senior citizens who did not speak Mandarin, while others complained of feeling alienated. In reaction to this, SMRT claimed that the announcements were only recorded in English and Mandarin because the Malay and Tamil names of stations sounded very similar to the English names.
In 2013, a group of Tamil speakers petitioned the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore to include Tamil instead of Japanese on all the signs in the Singapore Changi Airport. Even though only 5% of the Singapore population speaks Tamil, they argued that since Tamil is one of the four official languages of Singapore, it should be used to reflect Singapore's multi-racial background.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}}
In 2014, there were reports of erroneous translations on road signs of popular tourist attractions such as Lau Pa Sat and [[Gardens by the Bay]] made by the Singapore Tourism Board, mostly involving English to Tamil translations. According to ''The Straits Times'', rectifications are underway to ensure that the translations are now correct.<ref>http://www.straitstimes.com/news/singapore/more-singapore-stories/story/wrong-tamil-translation-lau-pa-sat-name-makes-its-rounds</ref>
==Media and the arts== The free-to-air channels in Singapore are run by [[MediaCorp]] and each channel is aired in one of the four official languages of Singapore. For example, [[MediaCorp Channel U|Channel U]] and [[MediaCorp Channel 8|Channel 8]] are Mandarin-medium channels, [[MediaCorp Channel 5|Channel 5]], [[MediaCorp okto|Okto]] and [[Channel News Asia]] are English-medium channels, [[MediaCorp Suria|Suria]] is a Malay-medium channel, and [[MediaCorp Vasantham|Vasantham]] is a predominantly Tamil-medium channel. However, these channels might also feature programmes in other languages. For example, apart from programmes in Mandarin, Channel U also broadcasts Korean television programmes at specific allotted times.
===Chinese varieties in local films=== The use of Chinese varieties other than Mandarin in Singapore media is restricted by the Ministry of Information, Communications and the Arts (MICA). The rationale given for the resistance towards nonstandard Chinese varieties was that their presence would hinder language learning of English and Mandarin.<ref name="Ng (2014)">{{cite journal|last1=Ng|first1=C.L.P.|year=2014|title=Mother tongue education in Singapore: Concerns, issues and controversies|url=|journal=Current Issues in Language Planning|volume=15|issue=4|pages=361–375|doi=10.1080/14664208.2014.927093}}</ref> However, in order to cater to older Singaporeans who speak only non-standard Chinese varieties, videos, VCDs, DVDs, paid subscription radio services and paid TV channels are exempted from MICA's restrictions. Two free-to-air channels, [[MediaCorp okto|Okto]] and [[MediaCorp Channel 8|Channel 8]], are also allowed to show operas and arthouse movies with some non-standard variety content, respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reach.gov.sg/TalkAbuzz/YourFeedbackOurResponse/tabid/108/mode/3/Default.aspx?ssFormAction=%5B%5BssBlogThread_VIEW%5D%5D&tid=%5B%5B122%5D%5D|work=REACH Singapore|location=Singapore|title=Provision of More Dialect Programmes|date=2009-03-26|accessdate=2014-02-01}}</ref>
The use of Chinese varieties is not controlled tightly in traditional arts, such as Chinese opera. As such, they have managed to survive, and even flourish in these areas. In Singapore, various types of Chinese opera include Hokkien, Teochew, Hainanese and Cantonese. In the past, this diversity encouraged the translation between varieties for scripts of popular stories. After the implementation of the bilingual policy and Speak Mandarin Campaign, Mandarin subtitles were introduced to help the audience understand the performances. Today, as usage of English rises, some opera troupes not only provide English subtitles but also English translations of their works. For these English-Chinese operas, subtitles may be provided in either Mandarin, other Chinese varieties, or both. In this way, Chinese opera will be able to reach out to a wider audience despite being variety-specific.<ref name="Local filmakers include more Chinese dialects in recent works"/>
Similar to Chinese opera, there are no language restrictions on entries for film festivals. In recent years, more local film makers have incorporated non-standard Chinese varieties into their films.<ref name="Local filmakers include more Chinese dialects in recent works">{{cite news|url=http://www.punggol.sg/forum/local_news_rss_feed_from_channel_newsasia/local_filmmakers_include_more_chinese_dialects_in_recent_works-t15604.0.html|type=reprint|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|location=Singapore|title=Local filmmakers include more Chinese dialects in recent works.|first=Lynlee|last=Foo|date=2008-07-06|accessdate=2010-10-17}}</ref> For example, the local movie ''[[881 (film)|881]]'' revived the popularity of getai after it was released. [[Getai]], which is mainly conducted in Hokkien and Teochew, became more popular with the younger generations since the release of the movie. On the effect triggered by the release of the movie ''[[881 (film)|881]]'', Professor Chua Beng Huat, Head of the Department of Sociology in the National University of Singapore (NUS), commented in the Straits Times that "''''putting Hokkien on the silver screen gives Hokkien a kind of rebellious effect. It's like the return of the repressed''."{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}} The success of 881 is also reflected by album sales of ''881'' movie soundtrack, which became the first local film soundtrack to hit platinum in Singapore.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sinema.sg/2007/10/20/interviews-eric-ng-on-881-soundtrack-2/|publisher=Sinema.Sg|title=Eric Ng on 881 Soundtrack 2|date=2007-10-20|accessdate=2010-11-18}}</ref> In other instances, the movie [http://www.tanpinpin.com/sgg/story.html ''Singapore Ga Ga''], a tissue seller sings a Hokkien song while ''[[Perth (film)|Perth]]'' features a Singaporean taxi driver using Hokkien and Cantonese. Local directors have commented that non-standard Chinese varieties are vital as there are some expressions which just cannot be put across in Mandarin Chinese, and that the different Chinese varieties are an important part of Singapore that adds a sense of authenticity that locals will enjoy.<ref name="Local filmakers include more Chinese dialects in recent works"/>
===Indian languages in the media=== Indian languages besides Tamil are managed slightly differently from the Chinese varieties. Even though only Tamil has official language status, there have been no attempts to discourage the use or spread of other Indian languages such as Bengali, Gujarati, Hindi, Malayalam, Punjabi, Telugu, and Urdu. For one, movies in these languages are shown in some local cinemas, such as Rex and Screens of Bombay Talkies.<ref>See [[List of cinemas in Singapore]].</ref> Furthermore, the local Indian TV channel [[MediaCorp Vasantham|Vasantham]] has also allocated specific programme timeslots to cater to the variety of Indian language speakers in Singapore.
===Language-specific societies=== Chinese clan associations play a role in maintaining the non-standard Chinese varieties. In the past, they provided support to migrant Chinese, based on the province they originated. Today, they provide a place for people who speak the same variety to gather and interact. For example, the [[Singapore Hokkien Huay Kuan|Hokkien Huay Kuan]] holds classes for performing arts, calligraphy, and [[Hokkien]] Chinese. They also organize the biennial Hokkien Festival, which aims to promote Hokkien customs and culture.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.asiaone.com/News/the%2BStraits%2BTimes/Story/A1Story20081015-93730.html|work=The Straits Times|location=Singapore|title=All things Hokkien in Fest|date=2008-10-15|accessdate=2010-11-17}}</ref> With such efforts, perhaps non-standard Chinese varieties in Singapore will be better equipped to resist erosion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chineseoperainstitute.com.sg/pic/Translation%20in%20Chinese%20Opera.doc|format=doc|publisher=Chinese Opera Institute|location=Singapore|title=Translation and Chinese Opera: The Singapore Experience|first=Soon Pong|last=Chua|year=2007|accessdate=2010-10-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110912003800/http://www.chineseoperainstitute.com.sg/pic/Translation%20in%20Chinese%20Opera.doc|archivedate=12 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Apart from the efforts to maintain local Chinese varieties, the Eurasian Association holds [[Kristang language|Kristang]] classes for people who are interested in learning Kristang. In this way, it hopes to preserve what it perceives to be a unique part of the Eurasian heritage in Singapore.<ref name="Voices"/>
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}

The '''Leopold Griffuel Prize''' (Prix Leopold Griffuel) is sponsored by the French ARC Foundation for Cancer Research.
The prize is designed to reward the accomplishments of and encourage further research among the world's leading [[cancer]] researchers. Past [[United States|American]] recipients of the Griffuel Prize include [[Samuel Broder]], former director of the National Cancer Institute; [[C. Everett Koop]], former U.S. Surgeon General, and [[Anita Roberts]], pioneer in research on TGF-beta.
Recipients receive a cash award of €150,000 (valued at approximately US$200,000 as of 2014).

The '''Longo Maï Co-operatives''' are a network of [[agricultural co-operatives]] with an [[anti-capitalist]] ideological focus. Founded in 1973 in [[Limans]] the network has spread in Europe and to Central America.
==History== [[File:Longo Mai Limans ETH Bibliothek Com LC0410-003.tif|thumb|The first co-operative in Limans]] Following the events of [[May 68]] groups of students from Austria and Switzerland who held [[anarchist]] ideologies collaborated to raise funds to allow them to buy land upon which to start to farm collectively. In 1973 they purchased 270 hectares of land at Limans near [[Forcalquier]].
The communities ideological leader was Roland Perrot, a military deserter from the [[Algerian War|war in Algeria]]. Perrot knew [[Jean Giono]] and had experienced the free commune in Contadour in the 1930s. The ideological focus of the community is anti-militarist and pacifist, anti-capitalist and egalitarian. Activities focus upon self-sufficiency, community life, craft and agricultural production, the joint management of energy, water and respect for the environment.
Longo Maï has been involved with various international solidarity efforts with a particular focus on resistance against dictatorships.
==Facilities== The ten Longo Mai co-operatives operate in a network:
* In France: ** Limans ** Briançon, [[Saint-Chaffrey]] ([[Hautes-Alpes]]) which processes 12 to 15 tons of wool a year ** Mas de Granier, the village of Caphan at [[Saint-Martin-de-Crau]] ([[Bouches-du-Rhone]]); ** Treyne, Chanéac, Upper [[Ardeche]] (twenty adults and twelve children in 1999) ** Cabrery, wine and olive trees * In other countries: ** Ulenkrug, [[Mecklenburg]], Germany; ** Hof Stopar Eisenkappel in [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]], Austria (17 hectares plus 25 hectares leased, breeding sheep) ** Montois farm in the [[Swiss Jura]] (12 ha geese and sheep) ** Uzhgorod, [[Zakarpattia Oblast|Transcarpathia]], Ukraine, with a French school in the 1990s ** Finca Sonador in [[Costa Rica]]<ref name="Longo Mai Costa Rica">{{cite web|url=http://www.sonador.info/en/ |title=Longo Mai, Costa Rica |publisher=Sonador.info |date= |accessdate=27 December 2011}}</ref>
The head office of the cooperative is in Basel, from which are organised campaigns to collect donations (about five million francs a year in the 1990s).
[[File:30 ans publics de radio zinzine.JPG|thumb|30 years of Radio Zinzine]] The cooperative also has media operations
* Radio Free Radio Zinzine: Founded in 1981 and named after the hill in Limans on which the community was founded. It is affiliated to the European Federation of Free Radio * a news agency, l'Agence Indépendante d'information (AIM), which has a hundred contributing journalists * le journal Archipel, Journal of the European Civic Forum * It also publishes some books.

The '''Los Angeles Tennis Club (LATC)''' is a private [[tennis]] club opened in 1920 that was the host of the [[Pacific Southwest Championships]] from 1927 until 1974 and 1980 until 1983. It is located at 5851 Clinton Street, between Wilcox and Rossmore, one block south of [[Melrose Avenue]]. It is currently the home of the [[Southern California Championships]].
==History== The club was founded in 1920 and [[Tom Bundy|Thomas C. Bundy]] was elected as its first president.<ref name=baltzell>{{cite book|last1=Baltzell|first1=E. Digby|authorlink= E. Digby Baltzell|title=Sporting Gentlemen : Men's Tennis from the Age of Honor to the Cult of the Superstar|date=1995|publisher=Free Press|location=New York [u.a.]|isbn=9780029013151|page=233}}</ref>
[[Perry T. Jones]] was a major fundraiser and took control of Southern California tennis in 1930. He set up his office at the Club with his loyal Secretary, Doris Cooke, and made it famous through his junior development patrons network. It reached from Santa Barbara to San Diego and came together at the LATC to produce a steady stream of world-class tennis players. dubbed "the cradle of tennis." Jones believed in schooling, cleanliness, proper attire, and sportsmanship when helping players develop into champions. He became Davis Cup Captain in 1958, recruited, mentored and named [[Alex Olmedo]] to the team, that included [[Barry MacKay]] and [[Ham Richardson]], and won the Davis Cup from Australia, that year. [[Jack Kramer]] and [[Pancho Gonzales]] acted as advisors to Jones. Jones was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in 1970. He established the [[Southern California Tennis Association (SCTA) Hall of Fame]] in 1968, and was known as "Mr. Tennis of the West Coast".
From the 1930s through the early 1970s, the LATC was the center of development for world-class players in the United States. In 1930, Perry T. Jones, became President of the [[Southern California Tennis Association]] and the Director of the [[Southern California Championships]] and [[Pacific Southwest Championships|Pacific Southwest Tennis Championships]]. [[Bill Tilden]] was the first winner of the Pacific Southwest tournament in 1927. Jones designed what he termed "The Factory System" that utilized [[Tennis Patrons]] in San Diego, Long Beach, Pasadena, Beverly Hills, and Santa Monica, such as: Harper Ink, Charles Lane, Dr. Ben Parks, Jack Lynch, Bob Martin, and Helen Roark; and Tennis Teachers: Mercer Beasley, Esther Bartosh, [[Ben Press]], Clyde Walker, Wilbur Folsom, Dick Skeen, Pancho Segura, Carl Earn, Eleanor Tennant, Linda Crosby, Vic Braden, Myron McNamara, and Robert Lansdorp to identify and funnel top-flight junior players to his attention, so he could make them champions with funding, top competition, and tournaments, such as: [[Ellsworth Vines]], [[Gene Mako]], [[Jack Tidball]], [[Jack Kramer]], [[Joe Hunt]], [[Pauline Betz]], [[Bobby Riggs]], [[Bob Falkenburg]], [[Pancho Gonzales]], [[Ted Schroeder]], [[Joe Hunt]], Dave Freeman, [[Budge Patty]], [[Dodo Cheney]], [[Herb Flam]], [[Hugh Stewart (tennis)|Hugh Stewart]], [[Pat Yeomans]], [[Gussie Moran]], [[Louise Brough]], [[Maureen Connolly]], [[Beverly Baker]], [[Alex Olmedo]], [[Darlene Hard]], [[Billie Jean King]], [[Sally Moore (tennis)|Sally Moore]], [[Karen Hantze]], [[Mike Franks (tennis)|Mike Franks]], [[Bill Bond (tennis)|Bill Bond]], [[Rafael Osuna]], [[Dennis Ralston]], [[Jon Douglas]], [[Allen Fox]], [[Stan Smith]], [[Charlie Pasarell]], [[Bob Lutz (tennis)|Bob Lutz]], [[George Toley]], and many others. Jack Kramer writes in his autobiography in 1979, that "if you wanted top competition, you had to play at the LATC — especially since there were many fewer tournaments then and practice was the vogue." Jones was a strong-willed autocrat who excluded the young [[Pancho Gonzales]] from the Club because of his school truancy. He sometimes would not sponsor [[Bobby Riggs]] for Eastern Tournaments. He also achieved notoriety for excluding a 12-year-old [[Billie Jean King]] from a group photo at the Club, because she was wearing shorts instead of a tennis dress.<ref>{{cite news | author=W.S. | title=A Clear Signal That Everything's Not For Sale | url=http://www.insidetennis.com/archive/0906_king.html | work=Inside Tennis | date=September 2006 | accessdate=September 5, 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110103122546/http://www.insidetennis.com/archive/0906_king.html | archivedate=January 3, 2011 | df= }}</ref>
In 1952, [[Angela Buxton]], who in 1956 won competitions at [[Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]] and the [[French Open|French Championship]]s, encountered [[anti-Semitism]] at the club. "They told me I couldn't play because I was [[Jew]]ish," she said. She trained elsewhere, and had the opportunity to work with [[Bill Tilden]].<ref>'''Great Jews in Sports''', Robert Slater (New York: Jonathan David Publishers, 2000)</ref><ref>'''Encyclopedia of JEWS in Sports''', Bernard Postal, Jesse Silver, and Roy Silver (New York: Bloch Publishing Co, 1965)</ref>
When he was still a teenage player, Kramer writes, he could "get matches against [[Ellsworth Vines]], [[Bill Tilden]], [[Bobby Riggs]], [[Gene Mako]], [[Joseph Hunt|Joe Hunt]], [[Ted Schroeder]], [[Jack Tidball]], [[Frank Shields]], and – often as not – the players on the [[UCLA]] and [[University of Southern California]] teams. [[George Toley]] won 10 NCAA Team Titles as Coach of USC, and was the Teaching Professional at the Club. [[Sidney Wood]] would come in for long periods from the East, and [[Frank Kovacs]] from Northern California." [[Bill Tilden|"Big Bill" Tilden]], the dominant player of the 1920s and the leading gate attraction of the 1930s, was a [[Philadelphia|Philadelphian]], who spent much of his time in Los Angeles and at the LATC, playing matches in the morning and [[Contract bridge|bridge]] in the afternoon.
For five decades, the Pacific Southwest Championships, open only to amateurs until 1968, and played at the LATC, was the second most prestigious American tennis tournament. In preparation for the [[1984 Summer Olympics]], Leonard Strauss, an LATC member and Chairman of [[Thrifty Drug Stores]], spearheaded construction of a new 5,800 seat tennis stadium on the UCLA campus, which now hosts Southern California's major annual professional tennis event.
==Today== The LATC remains an important tournament, recreation, and community resource for Los Angeles and its [[Hancock Park]] community. Owned by 360 equity members, the LATC provides 16 tennis courts along with pool, gym, dining, and bar facilities to its 400 members and their families and guests. The LATC continues to host several amateur, collegiate, and charity tournaments. It is a practice venue for the [[Loyola High School (Los Angeles)|Loyola High]] and [[Marlborough School (Los Angeles, California)|Marlborough School]] tennis teams.
As of 2017 the fee for new equity memberships is $25,000, not including quarterly and monthly dues, and new applicants undergo a lengthy acceptance process that can take several months and require direct approval of the board.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latennisclub.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Membership-Classes-1.1.171.pdf|title=LA Tennis Club Membership Classes|last=|first=|date=2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
